jdrasil.graph.invariants

Class Invariant<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>,Value,Image>

  • java.lang.Object
    • jdrasil.graph.invariants.Invariant<T,Value,Image>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the vertex type
    Value - the type of the invariant (@see getValue())
    Image - the type to which vertices are mapped (@see getModel())
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Clique, ConnectedComponents, Matching, MinimalSeparator, TwinDecomposition, VertexCover

    public abstract class Invariant<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>,Value,Image>
extends java.lang.Object
    A graph property is a class of graphs that is closed under isomorphism. A graph invariant is a function that maps isomorphic graphs to the same value. Examples for graph invariants are "number of vertices", "size of the minimum vertex-cover", etc.. An example of a graph property could be "contains a triangle". In this sense, we can model graph properties as invariants that map to boolean values. This class models a graph-invariant. In order to do so, it essentially provides the method @see getValue(), which returns the computed invariant. Since many invariants can be represented by an additional model (for instance, a model for the vertex-cover model is the actual vertex-cover), the class also provides the method @see getModel(), which returns a map from vertices to some values.

    • Field Summary

      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected Graph<T> graph
      The graph for which the invariant is computed.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Concrete Methods

      protected abstract java.util.Map<T,Image> computeModel()
      Compute a model of the invariant, i.e., a function that maps from vertices to the Image.
      protected abstract Value computeValue()
      Compute the value of the invariant, i.e., "the invariant".

      Returns a model of the invariant (computed by @see computeModel()).
      Value getValue()
      Returns the value of the invariant (computed by @see computeValue()).
      abstract boolean isExact()
      Many graph invariants are NP-hard or worse, therefore it is often not possible to compute them exact.

    • Field Detail

      • graph

        protected Graph<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>> graph
        The graph for which the invariant is computed.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Invariant

        public Invariant(Graph<T> graph)
        The constructor of the invariant for a fixed graph G. This method will invoke the computation of the invariant. In order to do so, it will call (in this order) the methods @see computeModel() and @see computeValue().
        Parameters:
        graph -

    • Method Detail

      • computeModel

        protected abstract java.util.Map<T,Image> computeModel()
        Compute a model of the invariant, i.e., a function that maps from vertices to the Image. This method will be invoked by the constructor and should not be called manually. As the name states, this method should do the computational task (i.e., actually computing the invariant / a model of it). This method will be called _before_ @see computeValue().
        Returns:

      • computeValue

        protected abstract Value computeValue()
        Compute the value of the invariant, i.e., "the invariant". This method will be invoked by the constructor and should not be called manually. As the name states, this method should do the computational task (i.e., actually computing the value). However, this method is called _after_ @see computeModel() and, therefore, the method @see getModel() is available during the evaluation of this method.
        Returns:

      • getValue

        public Value getValue()
        Returns the value of the invariant (computed by @see computeValue()). This method is just a getter and works in O(1).
        Returns:

      • getModel

        public java.util.Map<T,Image> getModel()
        Returns a model of the invariant (computed by @see computeModel()). This method is just a getter and works in O(1).
        Returns:

      • isExact

        public abstract boolean isExact()
        Many graph invariants are NP-hard or worse, therefore it is often not possible to compute them exact. A graph invariant can communicate with this method whether or not it is exact.
        Returns:
